Name: Triclosan
Description: Triclosan is an aromatic ether that is phenol which is substituted at C-5 by a chloro group and at C-2 by a 2,4-dichlorophenoxy group. It is widely used as a preservative and antimicrobial agent in personal care products such as soaps, skin creams, toothpaste and deodorants as well as in household items such as plastic chopping boards, sports equipment and shoes. It has a role as an antibacterial agent, a fungicide, an EC 1.5.1.3 (dihydrofolate reductase) inhibitor, an antimalarial, an EC 1.3.1.9 [enoyl-[acyl-carrier-protein] reductase (NADH)] inhibitor, a xenobiotic, a persistent organic pollutant and a drug allergen. It is a member of phenols, an aromatic ether, a dichlorobenzene and a member of monochlorobenzenes.

plant_concentrations.Value: Triclosan was detected in algae from Pecan Creek, TX downstream of a waste water treatment plant at concentrations of 109 to 146 ppb, upstream of the plant triclosan was not detected (detection limit 10 ppb), samples were collected Sept 2-5, 2005(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Adolfsson-Erici M et al; Chemosphere 46: 1485-9 (2002). Available from, as of Nov 20, 2017: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12002480 (2) Ramirez AJ et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 28: 2587-97 (2009) (3) Rudel H et al; Chemosphere 91: 1517-24 (2013)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Triclosan concentrations in fish bile from roach (Rutilis rutilis) caught 2.5 km downstream from the Garbo waste treatment plant, south west Sweden, eelpout (Zoarces viviparus) 1 and 2.5 km from the Ryaverken plant on the Swedish west coast, and in perch (Perca fluviatilis) 2 km from the Henriksdal outlet, Stockholm  Sweden were <0.01-4.4, <0.01-0.90, and <0.01-0.44 mg/kg, respectively(1). Triclosan was not detected (detection limit 38 ng/g) in fish sampled Aug to Nov 2006: 24 white sucker from West Chester, PA; 24 largemouth bass from Chicago, IL; 18 smallmouth buffalo from Dallas, TX; 17 bowfin from Orlando, FL; 18 common carp from Phoenix, AZ; 24 Sonora sucker from Gila Wilderness Area, NM(2). The concentration of triclosan in the muscle of bream (Abramis brama) collected 1994-2003 and 2008 from rivers in Germany (Saar, Rhine, Elbe, Mulde, Dessau, Saale, Wettin, Danube) was <0.2-3.4 ng/g wet weight (<2-69 ng/g lipid weight)(3).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Jungclaus GA et al; Environ Sci Technol 12: 88-96 (1978) (2) Klecka G et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 207:1-93 (2010) (3) Kumar KS et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 275-85 (2010) (4) Miller TR et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 4570-6 (2008) (5) Blair BD et al; Chemosphere 93: 2116-23 (2013) (6) Singer H et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 4998-5004 (2002) (7) Thomas KV et al; Chemosphere 49: 247-58 (2002) (8) Carmona E et al; Sci Total Environ 484: 53-63 (2014)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Triclosan was detected in sediment samples collected in the vicinity of an unspecified specialty chemicals plant in the US at 1.2-5 ppm(1). Triclosan was not detected in sediment samples taken from US streams in the Great Lakes basin from 1994 to 2000(2). In rivers around Savannah, GA, triclosan was detected in sediment from the Savannah, Ogeechee and Vernon River at concentrations of 2.5-12, 2.2-8.7 and 4.8-16 ng/g, respectively, samples were collected Oct 2007(3). Triclosan was detected in sediment from Wilshire Pond, located near the water treatment plant in Savannah, GA at a concentration of 581 ng/g, sampled Oct 2007(3). Triclosan concentrations in a sediment core sample from Chesapeake Bay, MD were <0.05 mg/kg at the depth of 0-20 cm and <0.01 mg/kg for 20-40 cm(4). Triclosan was detected at 12-150 ng/g in sediment samples collected May 15, 2009 and Apr 9, 2010 from seven locations in Lake Michigan(5). Triclosan was detected in sediment samples from Lake Greifensee in Switzerland at a concentration of 37.7 ng/g, collected autumn, 1998(6). Triclosan was detected, not quantified, in sediments collected from the Mersey River estuary in the UK during the summer of 2000; it was not detected in samples from the Tyne, Tees, Thames or Southampton Waters(7). Triclosan was not detected (quantification limit 29.5 ng/g) in 22 sediment samples collected Oct 2012 from the Turia River, Spain(8).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Miller TR et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 4570-6 (2008)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: Triclosan concentrations in a sediment core sample from Chesapeake Bay, MD were <0.05 mg/kg at the depth of 0-20 cm and <0.01 mg/kg for 20-40 cm(1).

SOIL: Triclosan was detected at 206.6 ng/g dry weight in soil 7 to 9 months after biosolids application. After 9 months concentrations decreased to 45.5 ng/g and down to 4.3 ng/g after 16 to 21 months following application(1).
